Issue 30

Installation View, Lorem, ispsum: Website Title © artists retain copyright

Phuc H. Le

Professor Holberton, Rhonda

ART104

5/16/2022

 

Final Project (Draft)

Abstract

    In this article, Phuc Le discusses the application of blockchain in the field of arts and crafts. In the time of globalization, mass produced commodities are a common sight, with each product having thousands of copies ready to be replaced at the moment of notice. Arts and crafts, for the most part, are still stuck in a limbo state of being priced based on their uniqueness–the more copies the artwork has, the less the work is appreciated. When blockchain technology started being applied in your average daily life, NFTs made a splash when the token was used in transaction for ownership of digital artwork; there were many ripples follow the splash, ranging from group advocating for NFTs to the right-click-save-as movement from the anti-NFTs group. This article plans on exploring NFTs, as well as non-NFT related applications of blockchain technology in the field of arts and crafts

 

Keywords

Blockchain, NFTs, Arts and Crafts, Capitalism, Consumerism, Art and Society, Art and Culture.

Disciplines

  • Arts and Humanities: History of Art, Architecture, and Archaeology: Contemporary Art
  • Arts and Humanities: Race, Ethnicity and Post-Colonial Studies
  • Arts and Humanities: Other Languages, Societies, and Cultures

 

Images

N/A at the moment

 

Introduction

  1. Thesis: Back in issue 13 of SWITCH, Steve Cisler wrote an article called “Arts, Crafts and Globalization” discussing the effect that globalization had on the field of arts and crafts around the world at the time. Steve noticed the chaos that was present in the market of arts and crafts at that time, such as folk arts being produced far from its place of origin, with the production chain with as many steps as that of an automobile’s production chain. Steve concluded his article by citing Professor Howard Besser’s use of computer databases to document the origin of arts and crafts. Years have gone by since issue 13, and we now live in a world with new technologies–I think the time has come for an article that can act as an update on these topics, and at the same time, a record of the contemporary state of the arts and crafts. 
  2. Introducing blockchain technology.
  3. Introduce insight on the relationship between an artwork, its artist, its place of origin and culture versus the global/internet culture.

 

Body

  1. Describe blockchain technology
    1. Origin of blockchain technology
    2. History of use of the technology
    3. Discuss the effects the technology has when it was introduced to the public.

 

  1. Dive deeper into the aspects of blockchain
    1. What applications does blockchain has
    2. What aspect is being utilized in arts and crafts?
    3. What has yet to be utilized in arts and crafts? 

 

  1. Discuss NFT
    1. Introduce and explain NFT
      1. How NFT is a derivative application of blockchain.
    2. Introduce the splash that NFT created
    3. How are sales being conducted?
    4. Discuss the ripples that splash created
    5. Discuss the importance of using NFT to verify the origin of the work of arts
      1. NFT is very environmentally unfriendly due to the power it required to mine a coin.
    6. Discuss the anti-NFT mentality of right-click-save-as (RCSA), and the copyrights law

 

  1. Discuss on the role of blockchain/NFT on building database of arts and crafts
    1. What is the benefit of building the database?
    2. Is it necessary to build such a database?
    3. What are the potential obstacles one might have when one attempts to build the database?

 

  1. Discuss the effect blockchain has on physical work of art.
    1. Is blockchain being used on physical work of arts?
    2. If it is, how is physical work of art being documented?
      1. Explore the effect on traditional artists.
  2. Legality in respect to blockchain and token
    1. Is there any country that is accepting crypto currency as one of their main currencies?
      1. Crypto currencies still aren't quite established, therefore the risk of a country adopting the currency is high since they would have a plan in place to prevent the panic caused by crypto currency falling in price.
    2. How does each country handle the legality of blockchain and token using the technology?

 

Conclusion

  1. Summarize my points
  2. Thoughts on the future

 

Bibliography

Arts, Crafts, and Globalization

Phuc Le

yourwebsite.com

Abstract

The author of this article-- Arts, Crafts, and Globalization --believed art to be the core of identity of an individual or a culture; however, with globazation taking place during the early 2000s, this core ingredient was becoming more and more muddled and confusing to identify. Factors that affects the "art identity" includes, but not limited to, the international trade, the use of computer internetworking that resulted in change in the practice of art creation, art collection, and dissemination of art of all kinds--but especially prevalent in folk arts. Example of this includes the existence of folk crafts around the globe in Indonesia, such as Mexican folk art in the style of Mexican dia de los muertos, silvers jewelry from the southwest of the United States, Agade crosses from Niger.

Keyword

  • Database
  • Documentation
  • Art Documentation
  • Digital Storage
  • Marketing
  • Globalization
